conversation.content: [coldly] I need a prosthetic index finger, left hand, and I understand you're the best in the city for realistic work. [pause] Money isn't an issue, but discretion is absolutely essential.
[professionally] Of course, I work with many clients who value privacy, especially those with visible differences they prefer to keep personal. [clears throat] May I ask how you lost the finger?
[sharply] An accident.
[carefully] I see.

The scarring is extensive, as you can see, and I need something that will look completely natural, something that won't draw any unwanted attention or questions from people. [quietly] Particularly from family.
[curious] Family can be complicated about these things, can't they? [pause] Sometimes the people closest to us have the hardest time accepting changes, even ones that help us heal.
[bitter] My stepdaughter wouldn't understand, she was too young when it happened, and her father prefers we don't discuss that particular evening. [sighs] Some stories are better left buried.
[gently] I've been doing this for fifteen years, and every scar tells a story, but not all stories need to be shared. [hesitantly] Though sometimes the body remembers what we try to forget.

[defensively] I remember everything perfectly clearly, the kitchen knife slipping while I was preparing dinner, the blood everywhere, my stepdaughter screaming from her highchair. [exhales] Children have such vivid imaginations about these things.

[slowly] Interesting that you mention a kitchen knife, because these scars look more like defensive wounds, the kind I usually see when someone's protecting themselves. [firmly] The angle is all wrong for a cooking accident.

[angrily] I didn't come here for your amateur forensic analysis, I came for a prosthetic finger! [loudly] Are you going to help me or should I find someone else who understands professional boundaries?

[calmly] I'll help you, but I need to document everything properly for insurance purposes, including photographs of the injury site. [pause] It's standard procedure, especially for traumatic amputations.

[frustrated] Fine, take your photographs, but I want them destroyed after the prosthetic is complete, and nothing goes into any permanent medical records. [threateningly] I have lawyers who are very particular about privacy violations.

[quietly] You know, I worked with a young woman last year who had similar scarring on her arms, defensive wounds from childhood. [carefully] She mentioned something about protecting her baby sister from their stepmother's rages.

[very quietly] That's impossible, she was only four years old when it happened, she couldn't possibly remember anything clearly enough to matter. [shaky voice] Children misremember things all the time.
Her name was Lily, said her sister was Emma, and she'd been searching for years to find out what really happened that night in the kitchen. [warmly] She remembered more than you'd think.
[whispering] Lily's dead, she died in a car accident five years ago, so whoever you met was lying to you. [gasps] This conversation is over.

[softly] Lily's very much alive, Mrs. Patterson, and she's actually in my waiting room right now, hoping to finally confront you after all these years. [pause] She recognized your name in my appointment book.
[panicking] You set me up, this whole thing was a trap! [furiously] You have no idea what that girl put our family through with her lies and accusations!

[firmly] The only trap here is the one you've been running from for twenty years, and maybe it's time to stop running. [sighs] Lily deserves the truth about why her sister Emma really can't speak anymore.

scenario: An evil stepmother visits a prosthetics artist to get a replacement finger, unaware that the artist has been working with her stepdaughter to uncover the truth about a violent incident from their childhood.
